posts.cooked: There has recently been a rather high profile OpSec failure that purportedly involved accidentally adding a user to a signal group chat that they should not have been apart of (see The Trump Administration Accidentally Texted Me Its War Plans - The Atlantic). I have no interest in commenting on politics nor on the appropriateness of signal for the conversation they were having, but the issue brings up a UX issue that I think is worth considering. That is, currently, while there is a notification sent to all users when a new user is added to a group chat, and forward secrecy prevents the compromise of previously sent messages in the event that someone is added to a group chat by mistake, there is still the possibility of a OpSec failure as mentioned in the article above. Thus I propose a simple mechanism. Add an option to group chats, implemented in the client, which requests a configurable number of group member confirmations before adding someone to a chat. The threat model is not a malicious client, as implementing this only in UI could of course be defeated by a single modified client ignoring the mechanism and adding a new user without other‚Äôs confirmation. The threat model is user error as in the story above. Enforcing some or all of the other users to also approve a group addition would serve as a check against such a mistake. It seems easy to implement. Simply send an event to the group and get a confirmation event back from the other users. Then any client which sees enough confirmations can execute the current new member add. If this seems reasonable, I am willing to open a PR for Android, though I would not be willing to implement it for other clients.

Proposal: Universal Member Approval for High-Security Signal Group Chats

In light of the recent incident where someone was mistakenly added to a sensitive group chat, I‚Äôd like to propose a new optional security feature for Signal group chats, specifically for high-security or sensitive conversations.

Feature Idea: Universal Member Approval

Goal:
Introduce an optional group setting where every existing member must approve any new participant before they can join and participate in the chat.

For new group chats created with this setting, everyone must approve everyone else before the chat can start.

Why This Matters

  1. Stronger Verification:
    Every member gets a chance to confirm the identity and legitimacy of a new member.

  2. Shared Responsibility:
    Security doesn‚Äôt rely solely on admins ‚Äî the whole group is involved in vetting.

  3. Prevents Accidental Leaks:
    Reduces the risk of adding the wrong person or allowing unintended access.

Implementation Suggestions

  • Opt-In Setting:
    This would be a toggle in group settings ‚Äî off by default.

  • Clear UI:
    A new member request would be visible to all. Only after unanimous approval would the person be added.

  • New Group Behavior:
    If the feature is enabled at creation, the chat won‚Äôt open until all members have approved each other.

  • Notifications:
    All members get a notification of pending approvals and when someone is fully approved or rejected.

Current Limitations

Signal already supports admin-only approvals when joining via a link, and allows control over who can send messages and edit group info.
But those protections center around admin control, and don‚Äôt guard well against human error or miscommunication during manual adds.

Conclusion

For extremely sensitive chats, an ‚Äúeveryone approves everyone‚Äù mode could prevent serious mistakes and increase group trust.
This wouldn‚Äôt be necessary for most chats ‚Äî but could be a valuable opt-in for activists, journalists, military, legal teams, or anyone needing the highest level of control.

Would love to hear what the community thinks
